author: working_joe
body:
OK it's really pretty easy. Imagine you want to buy a house that is worth $100,000. You put down a down-payment of 5%, or $5000.

Now let's say a month later you've done the appraisal and all the paperwork is ready and it's time to buy. But during that month something indirectly happened that affected the value of the house. 

Maybe Disney announced they were building a new park nearby and the value of the house doubled.
Maybe the city announced they were building a sewage plant nearby and the value of the house plummeted.

Either way, you've already got an option to buy the house at the $100,000 agreed on a month ago regardless of what the price is today. Notice I said option. You don't actually have to.

In the 1st example where the value went up, you can buy the house for $100,000 even though it's worth $200,000, instantly pocketing $100,000 profit in equity. Maybe Beyonce buys the house across the street and the house you wanted goes up to $5 million *in value*. The *cost* remains the same to you. You still get to buy it for $100,000. In theory the price of the house could skyrocket to any amount and you'd still only have to pay $100,000 since you secured that price when you put down the down payment. The possibilities for profit are endless, the sky is the limit. 

In the 2nd example where the price went down and they're building a sewage plant nearby, you decide you don't want the house anymore. You're not required to buy it, but you forfeit your down payment and lose $5000. No matter how much the value of the house has dropped, you can't possibly lose more than your $5000 down payment. 

So while the possible profits are infinite, the possible losses are capped at your initial down payment. 

Let's use that extreme example; Beyonce moves in next door and the house is worth $5 million now. You decide you just want the cash, you don't even care about the house. You want to pocket the money and you can go buy a different house. You sell the option to buy the house at $100,000 to someone else for say $4.6 Million. Not quite the full $5 million because they still have to buy the house, there's a lot of paperwork, etc. You never even owned the house, all you ever owned was the option to buy the house, but you sold that option to someone else and made a huge profit because you were smart (or lucky) and secured that option when the price was low.

This is almost exactly what call options are, with the most significant difference being that your 'down payment' is not applied to the cost of the stock if you choose to buy it. Instead it's paid like a fee for the privilege of buying the option. Otherwise it's pretty much the same. You buy an option today to lock in the price (called a strike price) to buy the stock next week, next month, or whenever you choose. If you locked in a price lower than the stock is actually worth you can either buy the stock at that lower price, or sell your option and let someone else buy the stock at that strike price. If the stock goes down below the strike price, you don't have the buy the stock, you just lose your deposit. So the profit potential is limitless, but your potential loss is capped at your deposit fee.

So let's look at a call option example using simple numbers.

Today's AMC price is $50. You think it will go up to $100 by next Friday. With a traditional long sale you just buy the stock at today's price and hope it goes up. If it's $100 next Friday you've made $50. If it's $200 you've made $150. If it's $10 you've lost $40. This is how you currently buy stock. The problem is your potential earnings is limited to how many shares you can afford to actually buy, and your potential loss is... well you could lose everything if the business goes bankrupt.

This is the beauty of call options. Options are pretty cheap, and you don't have to actually buy the shares. I can buy an option to buy 100 shares for a deposit fee of anywhere between maybe $1 to $15. Even though I don't have enough money to buy 100 shares, I do have enough money to pay for an option, knowing I have no intention of actually buying the stock. Instead, if the price of the stock moves up above what I guessed it would and what I have the option of paying (the strike price), I can sell the option to someone else who can afford to buy the stock. They're happy to buy it because they're getting the stock at less than market price, and I'm happy to make money selling the option. If my prediction was wrong, I'm not on the hook for buying the shares, I just forfeit my deposit.... times 100. Wait what? Times 100?! Yes but wait it's not as bad as it sounds. 1 option allows you to buy up to 100 shares, however you pay the deposit on each share if you buy the stock, and you forfeit the deposit on each share if you don't. It's not that bad though if you consider you could be buying stock at way below market value. 

So let's look at the example above again. If AMC is $50 today, and I think it will be $100 next Friday. I don't have enough money to buy many shares but I do have enough money to buy an option to buy the stock for $50 per share (the strike price) any time until the end of the day next Friday, that option only costs me a $10 deposit fee. That's all I need to put down today. Now if I'm right, and the price hits $100 next Friday, I could buy up to 100 shares for $50 each plus that $10 deposit on each share for a total of $60 per share. That $10 deposit seems steep times 100 but remember the stock is worth $100 so if I do exercise my option to buy all 100 shares I've made a $40 profit on each one.

$50 strike price +$10 deposit fee X 100 = $6000 cost to buy 100 shares
Value $100 per share X 100 = $10,000
Profit $4,000

Well why not just buy the 100 shares today for $50 each? You could, let's consider that.

$50 X 100 = $5000
Value $100 per share X 100 = $10,000
Profit $5,000

At first glance it seems like it simply makes more sense to just buy the stock and not bother with the call options at all. In this particular case with these particular numbers that would have been the smarter choice. But what if the value didn't go to $100? Let's look at some other scenarios.

First let's simply say you don't have $500 today to buy the 100 shares but you are expecting to have money next Friday. Well you could buy the shares next Friday but by then they're up to $100 each remember? You can only afford 50 shares instead of $100 and you have $0 profit. In this case where you don't have money right now, buying a call option today to lock in the price for next Friday would have been your better choice since you'd have 100 shares and $4000 profit instead of 50 shares and $0 profit.

What if you don't have $5000 to buy in today and you won't have $5000 by next Friday? Well remember you don't actually have to buy the stock. You can sell the option to someone else and let them buy it. You can buy an option today for just $10 and sell it before the end of the day next Friday for a profit as long as the share price hasn't dropped below the strike price + deposit fee. If it goes to $100 you'll be able to sell for somewhere around $2000. You don't get the full $10,000 of course because the guy you sell the option to still has to actually buy the stock himself. But still you can make a ton by selling your option as long as it's still at a profit (in the money). Worst case scenario it drops below the strike price you locked in and you are required to forfeit the deposit times 100 for a total loss of $1000. But that's the maximum you could lose, even if the stock drops to zero you're not required to buy it, you can't lose more than your deposit times 100 shares. While it seems like a big risk, your risk is capped, and the potential profits are ridiculous for very little investment. 

Some other factors to consider are determining the strike price and the expiration, as these both affect your deposit fee.

If the stock is at $50 today and you choose a strike price of $50, the deposit is kind of high ($10 per share) because there's a very good chance you will make a profit.
If the stock is at $50 today and you choose a strike price of $100, the deposit is lower (maybe $6 per share) because it's less likely that the price will go that high and your risk of losing your deposit is higher.
If the stock is at $50 today and you choose a strike price of $150, the deposit is much lower (maybe $3 per share) because it's very likely the price will not hit $150 per share and you will lose your deposit. 

The maximum strike price you can choose is capped at roughly 300% of the current share price.

You can actually choose a strike price *lower* than than today's price, however the deposit is extremely expensive because it's very likely that the price won't drop below the strike price. For example you can actually buy an option to buy AMC shares for 50¢ each! But it costs almost a $60 deposit fee PER SHARE, lol.

If the call option expires and you haven't sold it, your broker will automatically exercise it for you if you have enough buying power in your account. Otherwise it will automatically sell it for you. If the price has dropped below the strike price, the cost of the deposit times 100 will be deducted from your account.

author: HeinzKetchup5775

An index fund that tracks SPY.
One of my earliest ETF investment was VTI at 30k. I've never added to it since. It's worth 75k now.

SPY doubles in value every 6.5 to 7 years.

If you're not a stock picker, buying an index fund goes up slow and steady. No tremendous gains or losses. 

I'm a gambler now, i like to pick stocks. But 40% of my portfolio are index funds.

SPY annualized has returned 15% in like the last 15 years.

author: ImmySnommis
body:
The key here is believe.

I've been through every crash since 87. Just hold, assuming you have the time. Have a plan and stick to it. You don't KNOW if or when a crash will happen.

Now, to answer your hypothetical. If I absolutely KNEW a crash was imminent, I'd be jacked to the breast area with puts, then retire in style. If I only SUSPECTED a crash was imminent, I'd be in federally insured stuff like CDs or maybe even annuities.

But for real, I just hold.

author: bluehat9
body:
Jpmorgan is a bank. When banks lend money out, they get paid back+interest. That interest tends to be calculated based on federal funds rate. If they make a 30 year loan say at 4% interest, and then interests rates rise (as fed would do if inflation gets too hot), then the value of the cash flows of that loan are less. In other words, if they could give a loan today at 4% or in a month at 5.5%, they’d be better off waiting.

It’s sort of the opposite of consumers. People are afraid rates will rise in the future so they want to get mortgages now. 

Two sides of the same coin.

author: Wyzrobe
body:
Started saving as much as I could, starting around 1998-'99 or so.  Have always lived cheaply, mostly in rented rooms.  No girlfriend, no dog, no cat.  Moved to where the work is, whenever necessary.  It wasn't an enjoyable life, but survival came first.  

Went back to school in my thirties, spent most of my savings getting through that gauntlet, made it out the other side as a family doctor, and earnings are up a fair bit compared to before.  Still lived pretty much the same way as before, though.

I'm up to a million in savings now, about 10% of it from GME, a bit from AMD, but most of it from Boomer stocks.  Survival has long ceased to be a problem, but my thrifty habits are hard to change.

I'm not a miser, I don't have any particular love of money.  Just nothing good in my life to spend any of it on.

author: TimeRemove
body:
I was bullish on their business model/insane brand locality, but I am bearish on their management clearly being complete morons.    

Let's review:   

 - Cover up/dismiss a safety issue for months (someone literally died, lots of people injured).    
 - Contacted by a government agency and quietly asked to fix it in-house.   
 - Refuse, forcing an embarrassing public slap by a government agency.   
 - After being demolished online and in the media, finally back down and agree to a vague fix.    
 - Half-arse fix (software pin code, instead of safety stop/plastic shield) that took months to roll out.    
 - Now try to charge a subscription for the shit software fix.   

They seemingly don't understand the demographic that buys their products at all. Brand is their biggest asset, and they've just taken a dump on it then set it on fire. You really think people are going to be bragging to their friends about their $3K baby killing machine?

author: Mattras7
body:
I think these earnings show that Gamestop is succesfully transitioning to e-commerce, especially the sales improvement while significantly reducing brick-and-mortar stores. The assignment of the two Amazon people as CEO and CFO is again very bullish. All I want to see is this company turning a profit again.

But let's be honest, it didn't matter what the earnings were: the price was gonna drop after market anyways because of planned moves and bad liquidity. The real question is how the price will move tomorrow at market opening.

However, don't be fooled: there is no fundamental reasoning behind current price levels. The only reason it's there now is because of meme stock season/the short squeeze story. If you buy in now, better 'buckle up' for some heavy volatilty. Better have some diamond hands (and not just for the meme).

For the record, I bought shares early December at around $16 and I've held my shares ever since then so I feel like i'm pretty neutral on this topic. The company turnaround was the reason I bought in, the short squeeze thing just the cherry on top as it seemed improbable to me at the time. To me, the positive factor about the short percentage was just that the price was so low at the time, I could get in fairly cheaply.

Maybe I should have sold in January, but tbh I kind of believe that the shorters must have just delayed the inevitable or done some illegal stuff to not cause the MOASS back then. The stock was rocking at $400 with still an incredible amount of short %, genuinely don't know how they managed to get out of that situation. I think I'll just hold and if the squeeze happens then I'll sell, if it doesn't i'm fine with holding because this is probably the best trade I'll ever do in my life and I just like the stock ;)

author: luckyninja864
body: Imagine every one of you that paper handed were actually diamonds and didn’t sell. This price might be 60-70 right now. And every dollar this thing goes up will put pressure on the hedge funds to cover.

author: _L0ssless
body: This is the biggest catalyst, bears are fucked now, let’s gooooo!!!

author: fluidmoviestar
body:
Banks are now accepting 0.05% interest for roughly $750B from the Federal Reserve… if that’s the BEST investment they can make right now, it should be no wonder that they’re gasping for air. 

Chamath may have been right finally, short a bank.

author: FireFighterIsaac
body: CLOV and BB are a battleground right now.  I am holding steady on both.  CLOV shorted like crazy and they won't give it up easy.  Think it's time to pound our chest and keep the hammer swinging on it.

author: ProfessorPurrrrfect
body: 2% off ATHs is a Bear Market now

author: Rabus
body:
My friends were laughing at me buying 205C calls on top of my 200+ shares.

Guess who's laughing now fuckers.

author: TraditionalAd2800
body: I made $650k off GME. Then lost it on everything else lol now back up to $180k. AMC is bringing me back!

author: itsleis
body: Bro can you update this comment to explain Acebullape's reasoning? Because what the actual fuck, this is some top tier fake news shit here by OP. OP fucking asked him to donate to a pedophile organisation [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North\_American\_Man/Boy\_Love\_Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_American_Man/Boy_Love_Association), and when Acebullape refused, he called him out in this post, publically, and now the poor bro is getting spammed to hell. At least give AceBullApe a flair or some shit for being bothered like this.

author: throwawaycanadian
body:
Here's the thing, I've like what, quadrupled my money I think now? I wouldn't even know what to do with it if I did sell. 

I'd look at the cash and be like, well shit, I should buy some GME/AMC/BB

author: gosnailed
body:
Can you elaborate more on your thesis on why you think the housing market is going to crash? Think this could make for some good discussion. This is not 2007-2008 where people with no income and/or low credit scores are buying $700,000 homes. If anything I think housing prices will deflate a bit, but not crash. Now if there’s a broader market correction, then real estate will definitely suffer. 

https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-pandemic-ignited-a-housing-boombut-its-different-from-the-last-one-11615824558

Let me know what you think.
